presenter.name: Moon Jae Chung
presenter.title: Yonsei University
presenter.bio: Radial EUS anatomy in pancreatobiliary system

slide.title: Radial EUS anatomy in pancreatobiliary system
slide.titleNormalized: radial eus anatomy in pancreatobiliary system
slide.text: Radial EUS anatomy in pancreatobiliary system Moon Jae Chung Yonsei University

slide.title: Contents
slide.text: Contents Introduction Standard imaging techniques according to scanning position 1) Scanning from Stomach 2) Scanning in 2nd portion of duodenum 3) Scanning in bulb of duodenum 3. Landmark in EUS Phantom

slide.title: Current EUS system
slide.text: Current EUS system introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark 360°Electronic Radial Scanning Scope

slide.title: The potential benefits of EUS in PB diseases
slide.titleNormalized: the potential benefits of eus in pb diseases
slide.text: The potential benefits of EUS in PB diseases introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Advantages - Higher resolution without blind spots d/t the use of high- frequency ultrasonic waves emitted inside the body (vs. transabdomen sono) - Real-time observation (vs. MRCP) - Less invasive (vs. ERCP) Disadvantages - Highly operator-dependent - difficult to learn how to operate the equipment and how to analyze the images Phantom landmark

slide.title: Three Basic scanning positions
slide.text: Three Basic scanning positions introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Standard scanning methods
slide.text: Standard scanning methods introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark Position of the endoscopist and orientation of the handle of the scope

slide.title: Scanning from the stomach (A-CT)
slide.text: Scanning from the stomach (A-CT) introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Scanning from the stomach
slide.text: Scanning from the stomach introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark Insert the scope up to the gastric antrum After aspirating the air in the stomach, inflate the balloon Start scanning while slowly withdrawing the scope

slide.title: Scanning from the stomach
slide.text: Scanning from the stomach introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark Structures that we can observe at this scanning position are pancreatic body, tail and other organs such as spleen, kidney, vessels including splenic vein, splenic artery, and renal vessel.

slide.title: Scanning from the stomach
slide.text: Scanning from the stomach SA SV PC Portal confluence & SV introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark At this scanning position, you can see portal confluence that SMV and SV are joined.

slide.title: Scanning from the stomach
slide.text: Scanning from the stomach PC SV SMA Portal confluence & splenic vein Digital Human Anatomy and Endoscopic Ultrasonography, 2005 introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark golf club-head appearance

slide.title: Scanning from the stomach
slide.text: Scanning from the stomach Celiac trunk & Lt adrenal gland introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark “whale’s tail” “seagull”

slide.title: Scanning from the stomach
slide.text: Scanning from the stomach CA Ao SP SV Tail Body Genu Lt Kidney + + introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark Courtesy of Sung Hoon Kim

slide.title: Scanning from the stomach
slide.text: Scanning from the stomach introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Scanning from the stomach
slide.text: Scanning from the stomach Step 1: Search for the splenic artery/vein and SMA in order to identify the pancreatic parenchyma. introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Scanning from the stomach
slide.text: Scanning from the stomach Step 2: Withdraw the scope until the splenic artery/vein, left kidney, and spleen are visualized. introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Scanning from the stomach
slide.text: Scanning from the stomach Step 3: The main PD will be visualized with back-and-forth movement of the scope. introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Scanning from the stomach
slide.text: Scanning from the stomach Step 4: Try to scan the pancreatic tail. As pancreatic tail usually extends toward the head of the patient, withdraw the scope and visualize the left kidney and splenic hilum from the upper part of stomach. The bifurcation of the splenic vein is the index of the splenic hilum. The pancreatic tail will be visualized between the scope and these structures. introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Scanning from the stomach
slide.text: Scanning from the stomach Step 5: Fine back-and-forth movement of the scope will allow visualization of the pancreatic tail. introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Scanning from the stomach
slide.text: Scanning from the stomach Step 6: After locating the pancreatic body by scanning from the gastric body, withdraw the scope slightly and image the celiac, splenic, and common hepatic arteries. Check the lymph nodes. introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark “whale’s tail”

slide.title: Scanning from the stomach
slide.text: Scanning from the stomach Courtesy of Sung Hoon Kim introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Scanning from the duodenum
slide.text:
Scanning from the duodenum Visualized structures according to the each station
Station I (Inferior duodenal angle) Uncinate process, AoV, CBD, MPD
Station II (Descending duodenum)  Pancreatic head, PV, HA, CBD, GB
Station III (Duodenum bulb)  Proximal biliary tree, GB introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Scanning from the duodenum
slide.text: Scanning from the duodenum introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark Courtesy of Sung Hoon Kim Advance the tip of the scope to the apex of the duodenal bulb. Then, rotate the ‘‘right/left’’ knob to the right, and pull the scope back to obtain the short scope position as in ERCP (stretch technique). Then the scope will reach the descending part of the duodenum.

slide.title: Scanning from the descending duodenum
slide.text: Scanning from the descending duodenum introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark Digital Human Anatomy and Endoscopic Ultrasonography, 2005 Structures that we can from the descending duodenum are two echo free structures which is aorta and IVC and next to right side of two vessels are pancreas head.

slide.title: Scanning from the descending duodenum
slide.text: Scanning from the descending duodenum Step 1: Start scanning when the transducer reaches the inferior duodenal angle When the ‘‘up/down’’ knob is in the neutral position, the IVC and aorta should be observed as circular cross-sectional images. introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Scanning from the descending duodenum
slide.text: Scanning from the descending duodenum Step 2: Rotate the ‘‘up/down’’ knob in the ‘‘up’’ direction and perform scanning while withdrawing the scope until the longitudinal view of the aorta, IVC and the head of pancreas is obtained. introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Scanning from the descending duodenum
slide.text: Scanning from the descending duodenum Step 3: Withdrawal will allow visualization of a trianglar region with even lower echogenicity near to the scope. This transverse view is the level of the major papilla. introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Scanning from the descending duodenum
slide.text: Scanning from the descending duodenum Step 4: Further withdraw the scope slightly to image the bile and pancreatic duct terminals as tubular structures in the low-echoic region. The major papilla can be visualized more clearly with injection of deaerated water from the scope channel. introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Scanning from the descending duodenum
slide.text: Scanning from the descending duodenum Step 5: Withdraw the scope a little more to obtain the longitudinal view of the bile and pancreatic ducts. The ductal structure closer to the scope is the bile duct and the other is the pancreatic duct (Wirsung’s duct). introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Scanning from the descending duodenum
slide.text: Scanning from the descending duodenum introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark Courtesy of Sung Hoon Kim

slide.title: Scanning in bulb of duodenum
slide.text: Scanning in bulb of duodenum introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Duodenum bulb (or the gastric antrum)
slide.text: Duodenum bulb (or the gastric antrum) Pull Method Step 1: Insert the scope into the duodenal bulb. Inflate the balloon and start scanning while slowly withdrawing the scope . After observing the pancreatic head, clockwise rotation of the scope will enable visualization of the junction of the superior mesenteric, portal, and splenic veins. introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Duodenum bulb (or the gastric antrum)
slide.text: Step 2: Withdraw the scope slowly and scan the bile duct and gallbladder. The neck of the gallbladder will appear on the left side of the image and the fundus will be on the right. introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark Duodenum bulb (or the gastric antrum) Pull Method

slide.title: Duodenum bulb (or the gastric antrum)
slide.text: Step 1: Reinsert the scope into the duodenal bulb, aspirate the air, inﬂate the balloon, and start scanning. The GB will be visualized between the scope and liver. At this position, scan the gallbladder thoroughly, which can be achieved with careful back-and-forth movement of the scope. introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark Duodenum bulb (or the gastric antrum) Push Method

slide.title: Duodenum bulb (or the gastric antrum)
slide.text: Step 2: Advance the scope to the SDA. When the scope enters the descending part of the duodenum, the PV is imaged on the left side of the image and the BD is visualized as a tubular structure between the PV and scope. This area may include images of the cystic duct of the GB, the BD, the proper hepatic artery, and the PD as tubular structures. introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark Duodenum bulb (or the gastric antrum) Push Method

slide.title: Duodenum bulb (or the gastric antrum)
slide.text: Step 3: After the bile duct is visualized, trace it and push the scope with the fine tuning of the ‘‘up/down’’ and ‘‘right/left’’ knobs. This makes it possible to image the area near the major papilla. If you feel resistance, stop advancing the scope to avoid perforation. introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark Duodenum bulb (or the gastric antrum) Push Method

slide.title: Gallbladder
slide.text: introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark Gallbladder Pull method Push method

slide.title: Organs inside the EUS phantom
slide.text: introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark Organs inside the EUS phantom ● Aim of the training using the phantom 1. Understand how to delineate 2-3 major landmarks 2. Delineate the following 2-3 major landmarks from stomach for observation of pancreatic body and tail.

slide.title: Pancreatobiliary Phantom - Radial Scope (Olympus)
slide.text: Pancreatobiliary Phantom - Radial Scope (Olympus) introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Pancreatobiliary Phantom - Radial Scope (Olympus)
slide.text: Pancreatobiliary Phantom - Radial Scope (Olympus) introduction Scanning from stomach bulb of duodenum 2nd portion of duodenum Phantom landmark

slide.title: Take-home messages
slide.text:
Take-home messages In order to be an expert in radial EUS in pancreatobiliary system?
1. Understand basic maneuver and a sequence of procedures.
2. Get acquainted with landmark structures according to scanning positions.
3. Observe the expert’s procedure as much as possible.
4. And actually perform yourself !!

slide.title: Thank you for your attention
slide.text: Thank you for your attention.
